newsitem.title: GERMANY: Kohl says EMU should go ahead as planned.
newsitem.headline: Kohl says EMU should go ahead as planned.

text.p: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said on Wednesday that European monetary union should go ahead as planned in 1999 with as many countries as possible taking part that can fulfil strict entry terms on a sustained basis.
Addressing parliament, Kohl also said that devaluations within the Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM) currency grid would not be compatible with the goal of a strong euro currency.
"We need the Euro -- not at any time. We don't want to delay it. We want it now," Kohl told deputies on the second day of Germany's 1997 budget debate.
Kohl reemphasised Germany's position that as many countries as possible should join monetary union, as long as they can meet the strict criteria set by the Maastricht treaty.
"We want a hard currency and don't want to get into a weak currency situation. That is not arrogance, but comes from our experience in Germany over the past 50 years," Kohl said.
And, in an apparent reference to mounting calls in France for a devaluation of the franc, Kohl said such a move would damage prospects for keeping the euro hard.
"Suggestions to weaken the stability criteria or to devalue a certain currency in the European Monetary System are not compatible with this cause and are actually harmful for the future," Kohl said.
